Cramer's rule in civilised form with Clifford algebra

Robin K. S. Hankin

Source: vignettes/cramer_clifford.Rmd
cramer_clifford.Rmd

To cite the clifford package in publications please use Hankin (2022). This short document shows a nice application of Clifford algebras to linear algebra. Suppose we have vectors ğš,ğ›,ğœ{\mathbf a}, {\mathbf b}, {\mathbf c} spanning â„3\mathbb{R}^3 and are given ğ±âˆˆâ„3{\mathbf x}\in\mathbb{R}^3. We wish to write ğ±=Î±ğš+Î²ğ›+Î³ğœ{\mathbf x}=\alpha {\mathbf a}+\beta {\mathbf b}+\gamma {\mathbf c} for some Î±,Î²,Î³âˆˆâ„\alpha,\beta,\gamma\in\mathbb{R}. The traditional Cramerâ€™s rule for finding Î±,Î²,Î³\alpha,\beta,\gamma would be

Î±=det[x1b1c1x2b2c2x3b3c3]det[a1b1c1a2b2c2a3b3c3]Î²=det[a1x1c1a2x2c2a3x3c3]det[a1b1c1a2b2c2a3b3c3]Î³=det[a1b1x1a2b2x2a3b3x3]det[a1b1c1a2b2c2a3b3c3] \alpha=\frac{ \det\begin{bmatrix} x_1&b_1&c_1\\ x_2&b_2&c_2\\ x_3&b_3&c_3 \end{bmatrix} }{ \det\begin{bmatrix} a_1&b_1&c_1\\ a_2&b_2&c_2\\ a_3&b_3&c_3 \end{bmatrix} } \qquad\beta=\frac{ \det\begin{bmatrix} a_1&x_1&c_1\\ a_2&x_2&c_2\\ a_3&x_3&c_3 \end{bmatrix} }{ \det\begin{bmatrix} a_1&b_1&c_1\\ a_2&b_2&c_2\\ a_3&b_3&c_3 \end{bmatrix} } \qquad \gamma=\frac{ \det\begin{bmatrix} a_1&b_1&x_1\\ a_2&b_2&x_2\\ a_3&b_3&x_3 \end{bmatrix} }{ \det\begin{bmatrix} a_1&b_1&c_1\\ a_2&b_2&c_2\\ a_3&b_3&c_3 \end{bmatrix} }

where ğ±=(x1,x2,x3)T{\mathbf x}=(x_1,x_2,x_3)^T, ğš=(a1,a2,a3)T{\mathbf a}=(a_1,a_2,a_3)^T, ğ›=(b1,b2,b3)T{\mathbf b}=(b_1,b_2,b_3)^T and ğœ=(c1,c2,c3)T{\mathbf c}=(c_1,c_2,c_3)^T. However, observe that this solution, while accurate, requires one to take a coordinate basis; and offers little in the way of intuition.

Using Clifford algebra

Considering â„3\mathbb{R}^3 as a vector space and given vectors ğš,ğ›,ğœ{\mathbf a}, {\mathbf b}, {\mathbf c} spanning the space we can express any vector ğ±âˆˆâ„3{\mathbf x}\in\mathbb{R}^3 as

ğ±=(ğ±âˆ§ğ›âˆ§ğœğšâˆ§ğ›âˆ§ğœ)ğš+(ğšâˆ§ğ±âˆ§ğœğšâˆ§ğ›âˆ§ğœ)ğ›+(ğšâˆ§ğ›âˆ§ğ±ğšâˆ§ğ›âˆ§ğœ)ğœ\mathbf{x}= \left(\frac{{\mathbf x}\wedge{\mathbf b}\wedge{\mathbf c}}{{\mathbf a}\wedge{\mathbf b}\wedge{\mathbf c}}\right){\mathbf a}+ \left(\frac{{\mathbf a}\wedge{\mathbf x}\wedge{\mathbf c}}{{\mathbf a}\wedge{\mathbf b}\wedge{\mathbf c}}\right){\mathbf b}+ \left(\frac{{\mathbf a}\wedge{\mathbf b}\wedge{\mathbf x}}{{\mathbf a}\wedge{\mathbf b}\wedge{\mathbf c}}\right){\mathbf c}

which is Cramerâ€™s rule expressed directly in vector form (rather than components). Observe that the numerator and denominator of each bracketed term is a pseudoscalar; the ratio of two pseudoscalars is an ordinary scalar. Package idiom is straightforward:

a <- as.1vector(runif(3))
b <- as.1vector(runif(3))
c <- as.1vector(runif(3))

(x <- as.1vector(1:3))
## Element of a Clifford algebra, equal to
## + 1e_1 + 2e_2 + 3e_3
options(maxdim = 3)  # needed to drop() pseudoscalars
abc <- drop(a ^ b ^ c)

alpha <- drop(x ^ b ^ c)/abc
beta  <- drop(a ^ x ^ c)/abc
gamma <- drop(a ^ b ^ x)/abc

c(alpha,beta,gamma)
## [1] -3.805997 -5.328439  8.309581
alpha*a + beta*b + gamma*c
## Element of a Clifford algebra, equal to
## + 1e_1 + 2e_2 + 3e_3
Mod(alpha*a + beta*b + gamma*c-x)
## [1] 0

Thus we have expressed ğ±{\mathbf x} (except for possible roundoff error) as a linear combination of ğš,ğ›,ğœ{\mathbf a},{\mathbf b},{\mathbf c}, specifically ğ±=Î±ğš+Î²ğ›+Î³ğœ{\mathbf x}=\alpha{\mathbf a}+\beta{\mathbf b}+\gamma{\mathbf c}. Conversely, we might know the coefficients and try to determine them using package idiom. Here we will use 1,2,31,2,3 and suppose that ğ²=1ğš+2ğ›+3ğœ{\mathbf y}=1{\mathbf a}+2{\mathbf b}+3{\mathbf c}:

y <- a*1 + b*2 + c*3
c(
    drop(y ^ b ^ c)/abc,
    drop(a ^ y ^ c)/abc,
    drop(a ^ b ^ y)/abc
)
## [1] 1 2 3

Higher dimensional space

To accomplish this in arbitrary-dimensional space is straightforward. Here we consider â„5\mathbb{R}^{5}:

n <- 5                                                 # dimensionality of space
options(maxdim=5)                                      # safety precaution
x <- as.1vector(seq_len(n))                            # target vector
x
## Element of a Clifford algebra, equal to
## + 1e_1 + 2e_2 + 3e_3 + 4e_4 + 5e_5
L <- replicate(n,as.1vector(rnorm(n)),simplify=FALSE)  # spanning vectors
subst <- function(L,n,x){L[[n]] <- x; return(L)}       # list substitution
coeff <- function(n,L,x){
      drop(Reduce(`^`,subst(L,n,x))/Reduce(`^`,L))
}

Then the coefficients are given by:

(alpha <- sapply(seq_len(n),coeff,L,x))
## [1]  21.610237  27.030973  11.866383 -22.222116   3.199427

and we can reconstitute vector xx:

out <- as.clifford(0)
f <- function(i){alpha[i]*L[[i]]}
for(i in seq_len(n)){
      out <- out + f(i)
}
Mod(out-x)  # zero to numerical precision
## [1] 2.340649e-14

Or, somewhat slicker:

Reduce(`+`,sapply(seq_len(n),f,simplify=FALSE))
## Element of a Clifford algebra, equal to
## + 1e_1 + 2e_2 + 3e_3 + 4e_4 + 5e_5

Conversely, if we know the coefficients are, say, 15:11, then we would have

coeffs <- 15:11
x <- 0
for(i in seq_len(5)){x <- x + coeffs[i]*L[[i]]}
x
## Element of a Clifford algebra, equal to
## + 29.23618e_1 + 18.68409e_2 + 20.23065e_3 - 0.6361232e_4 - 40.82507e_5

And then to find the coefficients:

sapply(seq_len(n),coeff,L,x)
## [1] 15 14 13 12 11

Above we see that the original coefficients are recovered, up to numerical accuracy.

References

Hankin, R. K. S. 2022. â€œClifford Algebra in R.â€ arXiv. https://doi.org/10.48550/ARXIV.2209.13659.
